ground_truth_articulation: Text is classified as TRUE if the variance in word lengths (excluding spaces) exceeds 8.0, indicating highly inconsistent word length distribution.
generated_articulation: The output is True if the input contains at least one word longer than 10 characters (e.g., "antidisestablishmentarianism," "incomprehensibility," "implementation," "international," "sophisticated," "communication," "understanding," "conventional," "comprehensive," "programming," "extraordinarily," "inconceivability," "antidisestablishmentarianism," etc.); otherwise, it is False.
raw_response: The output is True if the input contains at least one word longer than 10 characters (e.g., "antidisestablishmentarianism," "incomprehensibility," "implementation," "international," "sophisticated," "communication," "understanding," "conventional," "comprehensive," "programming," "extraordinarily," "inconceivability," "antidisestablishmentarianism," etc.); otherwise, it is False.
llm_judge_reasoning: The ground truth rule classifies texts as TRUE based on the overall variability in word lengths, specifically when the variance exceeds 8.0, which indicates highly inconsistent or diverse word lengths within the text. In contrast, the generated rule classifies texts as TRUE solely if there is at least one very long word (longer than 10 characters). These criteria are fundamentally different: the first considers the distribution and spread of all word lengths, while the second focuses on the presence of a single long word. They may sometimes coincide—texts with very long words often have high variance—but they are not equivalent in core concept or in most cases. Therefore, they do not identify the same key features, and their classifications are unlikely to align consistently.
